Perry: s statement about the vaccination rate in Texas being 65 percent when he came into office and 95 percent when he left was fact-checked by The Washington Post's Fact Checker, who found that the actual vaccination rates were different according to federal data.
The Texas Department of State Health Ser: s vaccination rates over the years, which showed that the percentage of Texas children aged 19 months through 35 months receiving recommended shots increased during Perry's time as governor.
The Fact Checker also noted that Perry: s spokesperson later admitted that the numbers used by Perry were incomplete, suggesting that the figures he provided may not accurately reflect the true vaccination rates.
The expert: s verdict highlights the importance of using accurate and complete data when making claims about vaccination rates, and suggests that Perry's statement may have been misleading.
